Subject: Pole Balancing, physics maths and friction
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=8e2sPPXRCU1uWwfa_vAt5t-2sZ9oyOdYKAqq_MypnO_6-tKmUnTx
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Random observation du jour...

I've been refreshing/reviewing code and for the single pole balancing
task (as part of a wider sharpneat refactor/reboot), and also checking
the maths by referring back to some of the original papers that the
task originated from.

Two keys points:

 * An early choice was made to not include friction in the model as it
was deemed inconsequential to the problem at hand, and the difficulty
of the task (fair enough).

 * The update rules are based on Euler's method, which is a perfectly
fine choice, but it is a poorer approximation than e.g. classical
Runge-Kutta (fourth order or RK4).

So e.g. if I run the physics model with no force inputs, the
combination of the approximation errors and no friction causes the
pole to swing to a level higher than it started, and eventually just
spin increasing faster. I.e. the total system energy increases into
infinity :)

If I add in some more or less realistic coefficients of friction
(cart-track friction, and pole hinge friction) to stop the runaway
energy increase, then I found that the task is actually much easier to
solve (in NEAT runs), including for the task variant with no velocity
inputs to the neural net controller.

So I'm guessing here but it's possible that a significant part of the
difficulty of that task is in controlling the tendency for total
system energy runaway.

This is just for single pole; the double pole task uses different
update rules based on RK4, which I haven't reviewed yet.

Colin
